I love Shogun Total War. But I have to agree on the
accuracy of the game. I would love to play the
campaigns of Shimazu Yoshihisa and conquer Kyushu.
Then face the armies of Toyotomi Hideyoshi on my
terms. I don't like the map set up and what clans have
what province or that there are only 7 or 8 factions.
So my friends and I play the custom battles on line.
So we have one on one samurai battles between us.

Question to Nate. Is Nobunaga's Ambition available for
computer gamers. I remember it for the old Nentendo
system. It was one of my favorite(Takeda Shingen!!!).

Jake
--- Nate Ledbetter <ltdomer98@...> wrote:
> Shogun is a decent game--the second time they
> released
> it they called it "Samurai Swords", for whatever
> reason. It's the best board game about Japan I've
> seen...not familiar with too many others. 
> 
> I'm a big fan of Shogun:Total War and it's
> follow-ups,
> though they aren't the greatest accuracy wise, they
> make up for it in game play. And of course if you
> have
> access to Japanese games, the Nobunaga's Ambition
> (Nobunaga no Yabou) series is still going strong
> (just
> bought a new one a week or so ago!)
> 
> Nate
> 
> --- Kevin Burns <kevin@...-net.ne.jp> wrote:
> > What is your favourite game about Samurai history?
> > 
> > I live in Kanagawa, Japan and have done for many
> > years. I like it 
> > here.
> > 
> > So far my favourite is Shogun or Samurai Swords by
> > Milton Bradley. 
> > But I haven`t played so many yet. I have also
> played
> > a Japanese
> > game called Sekigahara by 6 Angles. Another game
> by
> > 6 Angles
> > depicted the Mongol invasion of Japan--the one
> where
> > the "Kamikaze"
> > or Divine Wind intervened. Another good
> > simulation--it game one the
> > feeling of being there, as much as a game can.
> > 
> > Your thoughts on games please.
> > 
> > Kevin
